importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of publication indicates the current relevance of the article in the context of ongoing climate-related challenges in Pakistan, particularly glacial lake outburst floods (GLOFs).

The date of Pakistan’s GLOF-II project launch highlights a long-standing government effort to mitigate climate risks through technological early warning systems, which has not yet achieved community trust or operational effectiveness.

The World Bank’s 2023 climate data showing Pakistan’s temperature rise emphasizes the country’s vulnerability to climate change, providing a scientific backdrop to the increasing frequency of GLOFs and floods.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from 2019 to 2022 saw nearly 90 glacial floods in Pakistan, illustrating a sustained pattern of climate-induced disasters that have driven community reliance on Indigenous knowledge systems.
This timeframe includes the most recent climate-related disaster waves and the growing urgency for effective, trusted early warning systems in northern Pakistan.

keyTakeAways: Indigenous knowledge, such as recognizing natural signs like rainfall, animal behavior, and sound patterns, is being used effectively by local communities in Pakistan to predict and respond to glacial lake outburst floods (GLOFs), especially in the absence of reliable technological early warning systems.

Despite a significant government investment of $37 million in the GLOF-II project (launched in 2017), the systems have failed to gain community trust due to malfunctioning equipment, lack of real-time integration, and poor follow-up actions by officials.
A critical lack of trust exists in official early warning systems, with villagers reporting that warnings have been issued by local residents—like shepherds—rather than by government sensors.

The combination of climate change (with Pakistan experiencing a 1.3°C temperature rise since 1950s) and mountainous geography makes northern Pakistan highly vulnerable to GLOFs, especially in Gilgit-Baltistan and Khyber Pakhtunkhwa.

The success of human-based, culturally embedded warning systems, such as gunfire signals and fire alerts, has demonstrated their effectiveness in saving lives, with no casualties reported in several events despite significant property loss.

namedEntities.name: Wasiyat Khan
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A shepherd from Roshan Valley, Ghizer, who survived a glacial lake outburst flood (GLOF) and used Indigenous knowledge to alert villagers, saving lives.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He is a central example of how local Indigenous knowledge and immediate human response have proven effective in real-time disaster situations where technology failed.

namedEntities.name: Mohammad Hussain
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A shepherd in Skardu Valley, Gilgit-Baltistan, who experienced a flash flood and used a pre-agreed gunfire signal to warn villagers.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His story illustrates the transmission of Indigenous warning methods across generations and their practical use in preventing loss of life.

namedEntities.name: Zaki Abbas
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An Islamabad-based journalist who writes on climate change and has reported on the failure of EWS implementation in Gilgit-Baltistan.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He provides external journalistic critique and insight into community distrust and political inaction regarding the EWS project.

namedEntities.name: Pakistan Meteorological Department
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The national agency responsible for monitoring weather and climate data and transmitting real-time EWS data.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is central to the official technological early warning system, but its system is criticized for lack of real-time connectivity and operational effectiveness in remote areas.

namedEntities.name: National Disaster Management Authority (NDMA)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The Pakistani government body monitoring and responding to climate-related disasters, including GLOFs.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It has issued projections about reduced snowfall and increased glacier retreat, and has acknowledged the growing threat of GLOFs in the region.

namedEntities.name: GLOF (Glacial Lake Outburst Flood)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A natural disaster caused by the sudden release of water from a glacial lake, common in northern Pakistan’s mountainous regions.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is the primary climate-related hazard driving the article’s focus on both technological and Indigenous responses.

namedEntities.name: GLOF-II Project
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A $37 million government-funded initiative launched in 2017 to improve early warning systems for GLOFs with new gauges, sirens, and training.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It represents a major technological intervention that has failed to gain community trust and has not replaced Indigenous knowledge systems in practice.

namedEntities.name: Gilgit-Baltistan
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A mountainous region in northern Pakistan known for its high glacial density and vulnerability to climate-driven disasters.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is the epicenter of the GLOF incidents and the main area where Indigenous knowledge systems are actively used.

namedEntities.name: Khyber Pakhtunkhwa
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A northern province in Pakistan that shares vulnerability to glacial and flash flooding with Gilgit-Baltistan.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is part of the broader region where EWS infrastructure exists but lacks community trust and effectiveness.

namedEntities.name: Skardu Valley
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A valley in Gilgit-Baltistan where Mohammad Hussain and others live and where flash flood incidents have been reported.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It serves as a specific geographical location where Indigenous warning practices are demonstrated and tested.

namedEntities.name: Roshan Valley
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A valley in Ghizer, where Wasiyat Khan lives and where a GLOF incident occurred.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is a real-world example of a community affected by GLOFs and relying on Indigenous knowledge for early warnings.

namedEntities.name: World Bank
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An international financial institution that assessed Pakistan’s climate change trends, noting a 1.3°C temperature rise since the 1950s.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Provides scientific data supporting the link between climate change and increased frequency of GLOFs in Pakistan.

namedEntities.name: United Nations Development Programme (UNDP)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An international agency that identified global challenges to early warning systems, including communication barriers and institutional weaknesses.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Offers a global context for the failure of EWS in Pakistan, reinforcing that the issue is systemic and not isolated.

namedEntities.name: Musadiq Malik
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Pakistan’s Climate Change Minister who emphasized the human cost of GLOFs and the country’s vulnerability.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He represents the official governmental stance on climate disaster risks and the need for better systems.

namedEntities.name: Friday Times
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Pakistani newspaper that reported on the failure of the GLOF-II project in June 2024.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It provides independent media validation of the public skepticism and operational failures of government EWS systems.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In northern Pakistan’s mountainous regions, particularly in Gilgit-Baltistan, Indigenous knowledge systems—such as recognizing unusual weather patterns, animal behavior, and using sound signals like gunfire—are being relied upon to predict and respond to glacial lake outburst floods (GLOFs), especially when government early warning systems fail. Despite a $37 million investment in the GLOF-II project since 2017, these systems have been criticized for malfunctioning, lack of real-time integration, and poor community engagement. Residents report that warnings have come from local shepherds, like Wasiyat Khan and Mohammad Hussain, who use traditional methods to alert villagers, resulting in safe evacuations and no casualties. This reliance on human-based, culturally embedded knowledge highlights a critical gap in Pakistan’s climate resilience strategy: the lack of trust in official systems due to inconsistent performance and poor communication, even as the country faces increasing climate threats due to rising temperatures and glacier melt.
title: How Indigenous knowledge is aiding Pakistan’s fight against climate change
